metadata.case_name: Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Dhenkanal v. Chief Justice and Judges of Orissa High Court

facts.text: Appellant was a Sub-Divisional Magistrate at Dhenkanal in the year 1957.

In a criminal matter before a Magistrate III class, Dhenkanal, an order under s. 522, Criminal Procedure Code was passed putting the complainant, one Golam Mohammed, in possession of some property. The order was executed on October 14, 1955.
The order was confirmed by the Additional District Magistrate in appeal.
The order was set aside by the High Court in revision on August 27, 1957.
Opposite party, one Sarif Beg, made an application on November 20, 1957 before the appellant for redelivery of possession. This was opposed by Golam Mohammed.

The application was heard by the appellant on November 21, 1957, order reserved till November 23, 1957, adjourned to November 27, 1957. On November 27, 1957, the application was allowed and compliance directed by December 2, 1957.

While proceedings were ongoing, Golam Mohammed made an application to the High Court for review of its previous order. By order dated November 25, 1957, this was admitted by P. V. Balakrishna Rao who granted interim stay of proceedings before the Sub-Divisional Magistrate but did not direct communication by telegram.

On November 26, 1957, an application bearing an illegible signature was made to the Magistrate stating that the petition being not maintainable, the opposite party had moved the High Court and further proceedings stayed until disposal of revision. Accompanied by telegram addressed to Mr. Neelakanth Misra, Pleader, Dhenkanal: 'Golam Mohammads case further proceedings stayed, Ram.'
It does not appear from the order sheet that Mr. Neelakanth Misra represented the complainant before the Magistrate.
On November 25, 1957, Sub-Divisional Magistrate was out of headquarters; second officer directed application be placed before SDM on return.
On November 27, 1957, Sub-Divisional Magistrate refused to act on telegram: 'No action can be taken on telegram, File.' Then proceeded to deliver order on opposite party's application.

Copy of High Court order received at Dhenkanal on November 28, 1957. SDM absent; second officer noted: 'Seen. A.D.Ms D.S. No. 326 dated 28-11-57. In Cr. Misc. Case No. 90/57 Honble High Court has stayed further proceedings. Stay further proceedings. Put up before S.D.M. Inform parties.' No writ for re-delivery issued; status quo maintained.
Upon perusal of records on August 18, 1957 in connection with review application, High Court ordered notice to appellant on August 25, 1958 to show cause why committed for contempt.

Appellant filed lengthy statement explaining facts, no intention to disobey, order passed because application not accompanied by affidavit or signed by complainant/lawyer, acted in good faith, tendered apology if found guilty.
High Court regarded apology as conditional, not accepted; found appellant guilty of contempt, sentenced to fine of Rs. 100; dismissed review application. Judgment dated November 7, 1958.

legal_issues.text: Whether it is necessary to make the Chief Justice and Judges of the High Court parties to an appeal against conviction for contempt by the High Court.
Whether the Sub-Divisional Magistrate committed contempt of court by disobeying the High Court's stay order.

petitioner_arguments.text: Had no slightest intention to disobey High Court orders; passed order on November 27, 1957 because complainant's application for stay not accompanied by affidavit nor signed by complainant or lawyer.
No intention to prejudice course of justice; acted in good faith in discharge of official duties; tendered apology.

respondent_arguments.text: In contempt matters, usual title is 'in re so and so'; no need to make Chief Justice and Judges parties.

court_reasoning.text: Judges of High Court deciding contempt matter not interested like litigants; no warrant for making them parties to appeal; practice should be discontinued; title should be 'in re the alleged contemner'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judges merely decide matter like any other decision.

court_reasoning.text: For subordinate court guilty of contempt by disobeying superior court order, disobedience must be intentional; requires knowledge of order from authorised/authentic source.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No room for inferring intention without knowledge.

court_reasoning.text: Application of Nov 26 had illegible signature, not countersigned by pleader, no affidavit; telegram addressed to pleader not shown to represent complainant, sender 'Ram' unidentified; not authentic source.
court_reasoning.key_observation: SDM entitled to ignore telegram and application.

court_reasoning.text: On receiving copy of HC order via ADM on Nov 28, proceedings stayed, no writ issued; shows no intention to disobey.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Status quo maintained upon authentic knowledge.

holdings.text: Chief Justice and Judges need not be made parties to appeals against High Court contempt convictions; title 'in re alleged contemner'.
Refusal to act on telegram did not amount to contempt of court as no intentional disobedience; knowledge not from authentic source.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ambard v. Attorney-General for Trinidad and Tobago
precedents_cited.relevance: Attorney General made party to appeal from contempt conviction.

statutes_cited.name: Criminal Procedure Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Order under s.522 CrPC for possession executed.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court's conviction for contempt set aside; no contempt committed by Sub-Divisional Magistrate.

key_quotes.text: "Before a subordinate court can be found guilty of disobeying the order of the superior court and thus to have committed contempt of court, it is necessary to show that the disobedience was intentional."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines requirement for contempt by subordinate court.

key_quotes.text: "The knowledge must, however, be obtained from a source which is either authorised or otherwise authentic."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to finding no contempt due to lack of authentic knowledge.

key_quotes.text: "We, therefore, hold that his refusal to act on the telegram did not amount to contempt of court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
